direction.raw_text: :    THIS IS A TRUE STORY EXT. KIGALI AIRPORT. DAY A burning white sun high in a clear blue sky, PAN DOWN TO: A rundown (sixties) airport, peeling in the heat. A mad traffic jam of cars, vans, motorbikes all stopped at a checkpoint where a RWANDAN POLICEMAN blows his whistle, waves some and stops others as bored Rwandan soldiers look on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON: A white van pulls out of traffic, a balls-out case of line jumping. HORNS, OBSCENITIES.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Extends from the passenger side of the van, Rwandan francs pressed neatly between thumb and palm. The van stops next to the policeman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr. Rusesabagina, good morning. In the passenger seat PAUL RUSESABAGINA, late 30's, flashes a smile. He is dressed in a sharp blue suit (always dressed in a neat suit and tie, it is a matter of pride). A quick shake of hands. Money passes from one to the other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY The van parked by the runway tarmac. African music plays on the radio. Paul drums his fingers, checks his watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: porter/driver, early thirties, sits nervously. An airport baggage handler approaches the van.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sir, the flight is delayed one more hour.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you. (to Zozo) He can get the beer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (suddenly worried) Rutaganda's place?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Beg your pardon sir, you are Hutu. You are safe there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are with me, Zozo, don't worry. Zozo throws the van into gear and speeds off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY The white van, marked "THE HOTEL MILLE COLLINES," whips its way through Kigali's packed streets and open-air markets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . KIGALI STREETS. DAY Zozo works THE HORN, weaves in and out of traffic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly, Zozo slows. Paul looks up, SEES: a gathering on the side of the road -- a large crowd of men dressed in exotically, yet identically colored shirts. They're members of the INTERAHAMWE - the Hutu Militia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . (Interahamwe - the Hutu Militia will de distinguished by these wildly colored shirts) They chant, drink beer, dance onto the road, obstructing cars, threatening the occupants. Several of them perform a rhythmic dance - the INTERAHAMWE war dance to thumping drumbeat music from a boombox.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Zozo, scared, looks for a side road, studies the traffic behind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The van pulls up beside the Militia.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some Militia approach. They are suddenly friendly, helpful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul reaches into his pocket, takes out some Rwandan dollars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the van pulls away Zozo looks to Paul, relieved.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What is it like to fly on a plane, sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It depends where you sit Zozo. In coach it is like the bus to Giterama.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That is why they call it coach?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe. But in business class there are fine wines, linens, Belgian chocolates.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (impressed) You have taken business class?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Many times.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Turn off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There is nowhere to turn, sir. As the van approaches,
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Slow down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Boys, do you know the way to Mr. Rutagunda's warehouse?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 It is one more mile on this road.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is thirsty work, let me treat you to some beers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY At his desk in front of a fan. GEORGE RUTAGUNDA, late 30's, huge, gold chains, Rolex watch, (like an African Mafia boss) but the same Interahamwe shirt. He squeezes an orange rind into a cup of espresso. Behind him, through his office window, the white van is being loaded with cases of beer. George holds out his massive shirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul sits opposite, sipping coffee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul studies his watch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: George leads Paul out into the warehouse. As a forklift lifts A WOODEN CRATE, George angers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The driver of the forklift, anxiously, spins the machine to return the crate but it slides off and CRASHES onto the floor: MACHETES, hundreds of them, spill out. An awkward moment then George picks one of the crude blades.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Off Zozo terrified.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You will join us at the rally today?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will try my best George but these days I have no time for rallies or politics.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Politics is power, Paul. And money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Time is money, George. We need extra beer today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Business is good at the hotel?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am always glad to see you Paul.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hell man, that is not beer, put it back!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But, sir, the Carlsberg is behind...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forget the Carlsberg, give him Grolsch. (to Paul) I won't charge extra.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A bargain buy, from China. Ten cents each, I'll get a dollar.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At least.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY A Sabena airliner lands. Passengers disembark via a roll-up staircase. Paul's van pulls up by the luggage belt. A large polystyrene box comes down the conveyor belt. It has Brussels - Kigali destination stickers all over it. As Zozo picks it up, water sloshes from the lid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Zozo goes to open it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul slips money to two customs officials.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The ice has melted!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't. Let's go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY The van speeds through traffic. More traffic jams, Zozo edges up on the sidewalk. Then at an intersection they see.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - a mass of young men and women, most in the same colorful uniform. Line after line, waves all performing the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: war dance, in wild hypnotic sync, many wave sticks, spears, wooden imitation guns. A large banner reads, "Hutu Power." A flatbed truck, speakers blare drumbeat music. On it GEORGE RUTAGUNDA dances the DANCE and waves a machete to the crowd. Zozo sinks down behind the wheel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The parade passes. As they wait Paul takes out the wad of notes George gave him, peels off a few dollars.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Zozo takes it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sit up, smile, Zozo, don't attract attention to yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Boss, some of those men are my neighbors, they know I'm Tutsi.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here, Zozo, for your trouble.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY The van turns off the street into The Milles Collines Hotel driveway and HONKS twice as it pulls down a short drive lined with tall shrubs. An ARMED GUARD rushes from his booth and lifts the gate. Perfectly timed. The van doesn't even have to slow as it passes. A sign on the guard house reads "WELCOME TO THE HOTEL MILLE COLLINES".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Lush tropical gardens, peacocks wander the well-manicured lawns,an exotic African paradise. The van heads to a magnificent colonial building.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A valet opens the front door of the hotel and looks shocked. It's unheard of for a service van to stop out front.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Pull up at the front door.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (urgent, to the valet) Help Zozo.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul leads Zozo and the valet into a magnificent lobby, a tasteful blend of Africa and Europe. Guests stare as water sloshes and spills from the crate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: early thirties the receptionist behind the desk throws a look of disapproval. Paul, imperial, snaps his finger toward him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gregoire engages a guest in chit-chat, ignores Paul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The elevator door opens and reveals BIK the Belgian hotel manager, mid-
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (re: spilled water) Gregoire. Take care of this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gregoire!   See to this right away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: s, reading some reports. He looks up, sees Paul and Zozo carrying the box as they step in. Bik looks puzzled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The elevator doors shut. Bik's left standing in disbelief.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's an emergency, sir. Now Bik sees the wet floor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Paul!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gregoire will deal with it, excuse me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY The crate is hefted onto a counter. The top pried off. A crowd of cooks gathers around Paul and Zozo as they peer in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They hoist up one end of the crate and LOBSTERS spill out. Many make it into the sink, but some miss and slide across the counter and fall onto the floor. The cooks sort the living from the dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cooks smells a dead lobster, shakes his head no.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul fixes his tie, very pleased, another crisis solved.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Any of them make it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Into the sink!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Twelve are dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How dead?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dump the bad meat, save the shells, fill them will ah, a stuffing, something local.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cassava, and Tipali.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. Call it 'fresh Scottish Lobster in a cassava and Tipali crush'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul inspects the tables' fresh flowers, sparkling crystal glasses. He looks to the bar - Grolsch on ice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The sound of African drums fills the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul emerges, as a troupe of African male dancers in ceremonial costume - Leopard skin dress, ostrich feather head dress, spears and shields perform a greeting dance for a the American Ambassador and a crowd of European dignitaries. The male dancers are joined by a troupe of young female dancers in similar ceremonial dress. The ceremony comes to a foot stomping finale. The guests break into LOUD APPLAUSE. Paul flings open double doors to a reception room and the crowd moves in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: helmets and arm bands)
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Ambassador, please come in. US AMBASSADOR Thank you, Paul. A UN Colonel, OLIVER, middle aged, Canadian,follows the US Ambassador. The Colonel wear the blue berets and armbands of UN Peacekeepers. (all UN troops will be distinguished by their bright blue berets, white
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Colonel Oliver, you are very welcome. The Ambassador shakes the Colonel's hand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Colonel. I'd like you to meet Mr. Colson, of our Regional Aid Division.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . COLSON, crew cut, military build, is obviously CIA.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Colonel Oliver is the liason officer for the U.N. peace keeping forces. Paul backs away unnoticed...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY ...then marches into the busy kitchen, claps his hands toward a gathering of waiters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A waiter whispers to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul heads out of the kitchen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Please, serve the hors d'ouvres now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: General Bizimungu wants to see you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY A luxurious lounge/club called the Kigali Club - an African Casablanca, complete with animal heads, a statue of a mountain gorilla, grand piano in the corner. Rwandan Hutu army officers, (distinguished by their crisp khaki uniforms, in the style of the French army), arms dealers, government dignitaries, businessmen and reporters mingle freely. The few tourists stand out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: heads to a table. The center of attention and conversation is General BIZIMUNGU, 40's, dressed in a crisp, heavily decorated uniform, a strong figure, relaxed, in control. GENERAL BIZIMUNGU Paul, this scotch is exceptional.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul heads for the lobby. He's intercepted by an zealous young Tutsi reporter BENEDICT who covers the political scene for the local independent newspaper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Benedict takes out his reporters notebook.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul laughs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's a single malt, Glenmorangie. I thought you'd like it. Anything you need, gentlemen, let me know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Paul, talk to the coat check, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Paul, Paul, a moment please. PAUL Yes, Benedict, what can I do? BENEDICT Can you get me into the Ambassador's reception?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, it's a private function.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At least tell me who is attending. The newspaper will be grateful.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will be grateful if you keep my name out of your newspaper. Wait here and you will see who has attended as they leave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul fixes a floral arrangement as he passes then arrives at the clock room hatch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul moves off as the coat check scurries away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An American woman, CONNIE DENVER, rich, blonde, surgically enhanced, stands by the door of the tourism office.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to the coat check) Did General Bizimungu bring a briefcase?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take it to the bar storeroom. Put three bottles of Glenmorangie... he writes it down on a pad) ...GLEN-MOR-AN-GIE, into it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Oh, Paul, Paul
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul walks into the tourism office. It is decorated with posters and photos of Rwanda's single most important economic asset - the rare silver back mountain Gorillas. There's a picture of the real-life Diane Fossey next to the movie poster for "Gorillas in the Mist". Numerous books and video cassettes. CONNIE DENVER's older husband, BOB, and four American friends wait.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Paul, Paul. Our trip has been cancelled.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, I'm sorry Madame Denver, it is because of the rebels.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rebels? What rebels?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't be stupid for Christ sake. The Watusis are invading the country. I told you not to come here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Tutsi rebels are far away on the border. And soon there will be peace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tutsis, Watutsis they'll still shoot you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But I came here to see the gorillas?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will try to arrange something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY The luncheon is in full swing. Paul glides in the background. Close on: The Ambassador in deep conversation with Oliver. US AMBASSADOR Things will calm down when the president signs the peace agreement with the rebels.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the Hutu government has been stockpiling weapons and are preparing a massacre.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rusesabagina.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oliver bursts out laughing. COLONEL OLIVER You're right, Mr. Ambassador, Paul knows how to get anything, even U.S. troops. The ambassador takes Paul's hand, shakes it warmly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul moves away graciously, and in one smooth move checks out, then pockets, the hundred dollar bill the ambassador palmed him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Our intelligence, Mr. Ambassador, is that
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's not what I hear. Excuse me. Paul. Paul comes over) Colonel, you know the house manager, Paul
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How was your meal, sir? US AMBASSADOR Magnificent. reads) Scottish lobster, in Rwanda. You see General what a genius this man is. You want anything, this man can get it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How about a battalion of U.S. Marines.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, General, don't ask for the impossible.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have heard, Mr. Ambassador, that they have discovered oil here, under Lake Kivu.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you for a wonderful meal, Paul.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY General Bizimungu gazes through glass into the reception room, SEES Paul shake hands and joke with the Ambassador. (He's impressed.) Paul notices the General. The General raises his briefcase and waves. Paul waves back. Another favor rendered.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT It is night now. Floodlights bathe the hotel in a warm glow. Tiki oil lamps illuminate the walkways and spread scented citronella smoke among the trees. Wild birds CALL OUT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Paul walks to the employee car park at the rear. He sees Gregoire and another male reception clerk tossing Zozo's pillbox porter's hat between them with Zozo trapped in the middle trying to jump and catch it. Gregoire thinks this tease is great fun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: he clerk sees Paul just as he's about to throw, miscalculates, the hat sails over Gregoire's head and lands at Paul's feet. Zozo scampers to pick it up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gregoire doesn't move.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gregoire bends, picks up the hat, hands it to Zozo, who walks away quickly. Gregoire and his friend turn to head back into the hotel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bik has walked out of the rear door and overheard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: disappear inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bik leans slightly closer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, Zozo, cockroaches can jump, some of them can fly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. (points to Gregoire) You pick it up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How are your dish-washing skills, Gregoire?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gregoire, there are no cockroaches in this hotel, do you understand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Cockroaches?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't tell me we have cockroaches, Paul? A sly smile breaks on Gregoire's face as he uses Bik's arrival to
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, Bik, it's a code word for Tutsis. BIK That's what I came to talk to you about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Hutu-Tutsi thing. The BBC faxed to say they would be here on the sixth for the peace accords. And the U.N. wants the banquet room for that day, a reception to broadcast the signing ceremony. Can you organize monitors and check the satellite dish?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Leave it to me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Also, could you remember to use the service entrance at all times?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Paul hops in his car and tosses a box of Belgium chocolates on the seat next to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Paul speeds through the streets of Kigali HUMMING along to music on the radio and eating chocolates from the box. He passes bicycles laden with produce. The song on the radio ends and local news comes on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul turns the station.    Finds another with music.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Good Hutus of Rwanda, beware. The dictatorship of the Tutsi cockroach is near. Watch your neighbor. Identify these cockroaches. Then rise up and stamp out this murderous infestation...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Lights burn in windows. Kids play soccer in dusty lots. Paul's van turns onto a residential street and slows. He HONKS twice. The metal gate to a walled compound swings open. A GUARD(old, peaked hat, bare feet, pathetic) stands just inside. Paul waves to him and pullsinto the courtyard, two cars are already parked there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT A neat bungalow and gardens behind the high wall. Paul parks and gets out. A DOG runs and greets him, BARKING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . His wife, TATIANA, a woman of great natural beauty, emerges from the house, beside her an even taller, very elegant woman, she has a doctor's bag and a stethoscope in her hand. This is ODETTE, their family doctor and close friend.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Down, Pealiss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good evening, Odette, who is sick this time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I asked Odette to take a look at little Anais. She has a rash.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your brother's here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, with Fedens and the children. e wants some advice.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good to see you, Paul. Paul embraces Odette warmly, kisses Tatiana.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I must go, Paul.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: You will not stay for dinner.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No thank you, Tatiana. PAUL My best to Jean Baptiste.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : PAUL'S HOUSE. NIGHT The old guard opens the gate, Odette drives off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT PAUL (a sigh) Thomas wants advice?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His brother-in-law THOMAS and sister-in-law FEDENS come out to greet Paul the Patriarch. They hug. Kids run everywhere. Paul spots his twin nieces Anais (in blue) and Carine (in yellow), four years old. He scoops them up, one in each arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anais reaches out her hand. Paul sets them on the ground, takes a chocolate from his chocolate box, deliberately hands it to Carine. Anais jumps up and down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes a chocolate gives it to Carine, then hands out the   chocolates to his children who are gathered around.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: He wants your wisdom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's have dinner first.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hello, Anais. She laughs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am Carine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are not Anais? ANAIS I am Anais.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, Carine, that is a shame. I have a present for Anais.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goodness, I cannot tell. I guess I must find another present.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY A crowded family table. Tatiana, Paul's four children, Thomas and Fedens, and the twins Anais and Carine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul's eldest, ROGER, 12, bows his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Food is passed around. Roger gobbles his down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roger takes off at a run.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Roger, your turn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For food and clothes, and all that grows, etc, etc. Dear Lord, thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Roger.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why the hurry, Roger?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Simon has a new pet. Can I go see it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I don't want you going on the street.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, papa, I have a secret path. PAUL Who is this Simon?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Simon, next door, the Charingas' boy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Homework?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's done.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And he did extra chores.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wash your things, and be back soon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Roger runs to a wooden fence, gets down, moves two boards and squeezes through into a path, almost a tunnel in dense reeds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Roger crawls along his path. There's a gap a little way down, and Roger shoots through it into the wide open of the neighbors yard. He runs to a back window of the house and taps on it. Soon SIMON, 12, appears. He slides it open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Simon lets Roger in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let's feed it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Roger holds a WILDLY COLORED SNAKE in a jar. Simon has a bag of bugs. Waves the bag in front of the snake. It's forked tongue goes wild.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Simon hands him the bugs. Roger lifts the lid, drops one bug in, and the snake strikes. The boys jump back, laugh.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT After dinner coffee for the adults. Tatiana, Thomas and Fedens at the table. Paul, in his usual position, at the head, listening, like Solomon.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I've heard bad things, Paul. My assistant says we should get out of Rwanda.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why should we leave? I have a new job, things have never been better for us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What good is it if we are murdered in our bed?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your assistant, he is Hutu?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, and he is in the Hutu Power Militia.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He wants your job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, he is a friend, but he tells me to listen to the radio. All day they talk about the great slaughter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That station is filth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: has listened, now he decides to speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Solomon has spoken. Fedens smiles, Tatiana rubs Paul's arm.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Today I talked to my friend the American Ambassador and Colonel Oliver of the United Nations. They are preparing a banquet for the peace signing. The BBC are flying in their best reporters. The world is watching. There will be peace. Don't listen to this man.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Roger crawls along his grass tunnel. Then he hears something. He looks through the reeds toward the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Military boots, a cluster of Hutu soldiers in their crisp Khaki uniforms. He hears whispering.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) That house.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Paul, Tatiana, are by Thomas's car. They say good night to their guests. Anais and Carine sleep in the car. Paul nods to the old guard to go open the gate. Just then Roger emerges from the thicket, wide-eyed, afraid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul nods to Tatiana to take Roger inside. Thomas and Fedens grab the sleeping twins from their car. Paul goes to his big metal gates and peers through the two inch gap E between the gate hinge and the gate post.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There are soldiers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On the street.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : (two houses down) the group of Hutu soldiers, clustered around jeeps, they whisper and point. It's a raid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Now they move rushing out of view. The sounds of SPLINTERING WOOD, GLASS BREAKING, CHILDREN'S CRIES, WOMEN SCREAMING. Suddenly there's a face, beside Paul's. It's Tatiana.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks, sees the soldiers, as they drag a middle-aged man onto the street. He is crying, pleading, like a whipped dog.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They watch as Victor is beaten to the jeep. At this point Victor looses it completely, stops pleading, grabs on to a soldier, clinging, screaming like a terrified child - like a man who knows he is going to die. It's a horror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tatiana, moves toward the gate handle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul grabs her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul takes her by the arm, leads her to the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thomas and Fedens wait, anxious, as Paul appears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tatiana hides her anger.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, my God, it's Victor. Why do they want Victor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Call your friends in the army. Call someone. Victor is harmless. This is a mistake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, be quiet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to talk to them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We must do something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What would you have us do? Argue with these madmen? We cannot interfere.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . NIGHT
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You better stay the night, it is too dangerous to be on the streets.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll fix a bed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Paul lies in bed unable to sleep.   The clock reads 3:00 am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His turn away indicates the discussion is over.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why didn't you call your contacts in the army?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I couldn't help.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You could have asked for a favor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I could not. What do you know about favors Tatiana, about barter and deals? All day long I work to please this officer, that diplomat, this tourist. To store up favors so that if there is a time when my family need help I have powerful people I can call upon. Now you would have me waste a precious favor on a stranger.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Victor was not a stranger, he was our neighbor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was not family. Family is all that matters. Do you think if you or I were being dragged from here, any one of them would lift a finger to help us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They do not have your connections.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Connections? I have no connections, only favors. If I call to help Victor, a General will think "Paul Rusesabagina is a fool. He thinks my favors are so numerous and so insignificant as to waste them on everybody." Then my hard work is doubly squandered. I insult the General and I do not get to use my favor at all. Please leave these things to my good judgment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MORNING Paul's car rolls up to the hotel's guard house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : APRIL 6th, 1994. An army jeep is parked just inside. General Bizimungu is in the passenger seat, talking into a walkie-talkie. The General gives an I'll see you soon wave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY The hotel entrance is a mini-jam of airport buses, white UN jeeps, foreign news crew Land Rovers, and a TV repair van unloading monitors. Paul marches in, past Zozo the bell hop, who helps the TV men unload.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Welcome, gentlemen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY The lobby buzzes with activity. At the reception, Gregoire is surrounded by a BBC news crew: GLORIA, young, chic female reporter/producer, and JOCK, tough, experienced Scottish cameraman, and his local sound guy Peter. Gloria is upset.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Jock sees Paul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul moves behind the desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He punches into the computer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Close on the computer: It clearly states BBC - two rooms.   Gregoire looks to Paul with a mix of puzzlement and anger. Of course, the BBC, five rooms. (lies) They are being prepared as we speak. I have ordered fresh flowers and complimentary champagne. Gloria picks up her bag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul better come up with three rooms fast. Then he spots the reporter Benedict hovering at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul hurries over to Benedict.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They join the BBC team.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gloria, a consummate news producer, turns on the charm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul moves off to the desk, Gregoire can barely disguise his pleasure.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gregoire hands it over. Paul dials.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul hangs up, turns to Gregoire.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We reserved five rooms not two
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, ma'am, but I see only two here in the computer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Paul, how the hell are ya'? PAUL I am delighted to see you, Mr. Daglish.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They moved you from the Diplomat?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Promoted. House Manager.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good for you. (moves closer) We're having a little trouble, Paul. We booked five rooms, but...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me check.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ah, I see the mistake. You were reading
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: - the Canadian broadcasting people instead of BBC Gregoire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Great, I really need a shower.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just give me a moment to get your keys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Gloria) Excuse me for one second.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Benedict, you should meet the BBC people. They could use your expertise. Benedict is delighted. They head back across the lobby.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whisper) Benedict, General Bizimungu will be here any moment. The BBC should talk to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Madame, this is Benedict Nangori, one of our best journalists. He covers all the big stories. I thought you should meet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Benedict, beautiful name. I'm Gloria Fleming. BBC.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There are no more rooms.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give me the phone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Madame Denver. I have very good news. I have a present for you, in return for the cancellation of your gorilla expedition I have arranged a safari at Lake Kivu lodge. A wonderful experience. No, no extra charge. A luxury coach will leave in one hour. I'll send maids up to help you all pack. You're welcome.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Call Kivu Lodge, ask for George, tell him I need three rooms. And send a team of maids up to the Americans. I want those rooms turned around in twenty minutes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: heads for the glass doors and sees:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY General Bizimungu, briefcase in hand, gives the tv interview, He's confident, controlled Benedict stands close by as Gloria interviews.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There are rumors, General, that your army, the Hutu army, consider these peace accords a sellout to the Tutsi rebels.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughs) Nonsense. At this moment we are making plans to rehabilitate the dissidents into our armed forces.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then the army fully supports the president as he signs the peace agreement.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Of course, the president is a clever man, he knows what he is doing. Thank you for coming to Rwanda. (on the move). You will see what a beautiful country this is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul turns, walks past porters ferrying the BBC luggage. He puts his hand out. Gregoire hands him keys. Paul does his rounds. He double checks the banquet room where technicians install several TV monitors and test the signal. He looks in the kitchen, frenzied activity. He wanders behind the bar. Everything is 'under control'. He returns to the lobby, greets Connie, her flustered husband and their friends, followed by a team of porters and luggage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gen. Bizimungu, takes Paul's arm, pulls him aside, hands him his empty briefcase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As the General disappears into the bar, Paul waves over the coat check, hands her the briefcase.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She nods, hurries off just as the BBC crew appears. Paul hands out keys, greets each.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jock, the Scottish cameraman, hangs behind as the others leave, takes his key.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul calls Zozo over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jock gets the code instantly, as Zozo smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Scot and Zozo greet, then hurry off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Forgive the hurry but I do not want you to miss the lunch buffet on the paddle steamer across the lake. It is the most spectacular sight in all Africa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lunch? All we do is eat. I thought there was famine in Africa. PAUL Exactly, we can't have our guests starving. What would they think of the Mille Collines back in the United States?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Keep that cockroach Benedict away from me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Same as last time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The fifth room is your broadcast room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good. I'd like to book a massage. PAUL Of course.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you bring any of those wee girls who used to sit at the bar in the Diplomat with you? You know? PAUL I'm sorry, Mr. Daglish, this is the Mille Collines. No working girls here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can we phone them in, Paul?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm afraid I can't do that, Mr. Daglish. Ah, Zozo.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You remember Zozo, from the Diplomat?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Zozo! The very man!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul supervises waiters hanging a banner.   It reads "Peace, Love, and Brotherhood! UNAMIR 1994".
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Reporters watch rows of TVs. All broadcast the signing of the Arusha Accords. (Reporters have political chatter.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON: the TVs as President Habyarimana signs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All the African reporters in the room CHEER. Fireworks go off outside the hotel. Colonel Oliver raises a glass of champagne and leads the room in a toast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The room as one raise their glasses.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: As president Habyarimana signs a peace accord between the Tutsi rebels and his Hutu army there remains strong doubts that the extremist Hutu Power will abide by the accords. But for now hope has returned to Rwanda for the first time in many years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To Peace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ON: Paul as he nods to a member of the tribal band on the small stage. Then, African drummers hammer out a fast uplifting beat as the full troupe of ceremonial dancers skip into the room in celebration.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul checks out the banques. They appear empty, then a voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's General Bizimungu, he is sitting with George Rutagunda now in a shiny blue suit. A bottle of whiskey on the table is almost gone. Bizimungu and Rutagunda watch the peace celebration across the lobby. GENERAL BIZIMUNGU Have a drink. He pours. George points his glass toward the Europeans.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rutagunda staggers to his feet, launches into a drunken version of the Hutu Militia War Dance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul takes George's arm, does two steps of the dance, then   appears to stumble and shoulder bumps the big man. George falls into his chair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rutagunda bursts out laughing, toasts:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Paul is forced to join in the toast, Rutagunda laughs, Bizimungu smiles at some insider joke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reporters and crews pack up their equipment. Paul shakes hands, orders porters to pick up cases. Then a porter whispers a message to Paul.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Paul, join us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look at them, they want to see the tribes dance to their tune. Here is our dance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, Paul. Show them our dance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forgive me, George, my step was off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To our president. May he find peace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . EVENING
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, gentlemen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Paul emerges, discovers Fedens and Thomas - they look embarrassed to be in such exulted surroundings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . HOTEL POOL TERRACE. NIGHT Drinks are served at a table as Paul listens to Thomas.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul stifles his anger.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Forgive us, Paul. We must talk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We are leaving Rwanda, Paul.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go to the terrace, I will join you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My assistant, the Hutu Power man, says we should get out now, that soon it will be very bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give me this man's name.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His name is Naramaranga, but please, Paul, even though he is Hutu Power, he is a friend, he likes me. He told me there is a signal. It is "Cut the tall trees." When they hear the signal, the militia are to go to war.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, let us take Tatiana with us. You are Hutu, you will be safe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thomas, Fedens, I am a man who looks after his family. If there were danger I would be the first to leave?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - a distant explosion, a flash of light on the far side of the city. Fedens jumps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Zozo hands Paul a cordless phone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What was that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Calm yourself, it is fireworks to celebrate the peace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, Paul, tomorrow I will bring you my car. You will sell it for me and get a fair price. We will go to Tanzania until there is real peace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, Paul, you have a call.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ello. Tatsi. Yes, they are here. Yes. I know but I want them to calm down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: and Fedens listen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hangs up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Already the press are packing their bags. The BBC man told me there's no story here. We are boring now. I'll be home soon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let us all go home and sleep.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . EVENING Paul escorts Fedens and Thomas to their car.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Call when you get home.   And don't worry, Thomas. Good night.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Paul's at the wheel, driving. A thick mist. Barely a car on the road. Shadows dart past faint house lights. The windscreen clouds. Paul switches on his wipers. A Toyota truck, loaded with Militia, appears from the mist, speeds past. Paul switches the preset buttons on the radio as he drives. He can only find fevered drum-based MUSIC.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Paul turns onto his street. The houses are dark: windows shuttered; gates closed; not a soul about. Paul stops before his gate. HONKS twice. The gate doesn't open. He hops out and opens it with a key. Gives it a push and pauses as he heads back to the car. He hears the far off sound of gunfire. Distant explosions light the night sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Paul drives in. His compound is curiously dark.     His headlights sweep across his pitch-black house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : The gates swing shut. We PULL BACK as Paul turns and faces his house. Paul whistles for the dog, nothing. He goes back to the car, gets a flashlight, heads for the front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT The door slowly opens. Paul steps in quietly, tries the light switch, nothing. He listens. The only sounds are distant explosions and gunfire. The beam of his flashlight cuts the blackness, illuminating: magazines arranged on a coffee table; an empty chair; children's toys in a basket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Paul continues his search. Scans the counter. There's food on the stove. The table is set. He hears a GROWL, quickly cut short, from one of the bedrooms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Paul shines the light into a room. Looks for a second, then closes the door, and walks to the next. He stops and listens with his ear to the door. Nothing. He pushes it in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Paul's light sweeps across the room and illuminates: Eyes - terrified eyes, a room full of faces, staring back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : A dark figure behind a blinding light. The dog breaks free, runs to Paul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From among the faces, Tatiana's voice heavy with relief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul's eyes adjust, he recognizes many of his neighbors, all crowded into this small room. Then he sees their friends Odette and her husband Jean Baptiste.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tatiana pulls Paul aside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jean Baptiste turns on his tiny radio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The words are cut short as a grenade blast rattles the window. Everyone jumps, children whimper. Paul is shocked but tries to pull things together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He holds the door open, they file out, frightened. Tatiana is last, he stops her, steps back in, closes the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The door knocks.   Paul gets up, angry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul opens the door, it's Odette, holding the hand of Paul's eldest daughter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tatiana comes over instantly, worried.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Pealiss!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Paul!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Jean Baptiste!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Our house has been burned.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is going on?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The president has been murdered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Murdered! By whom?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The radio says Tutsi rebels.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nonsense. Why would the rebels kill the president when he agreed to peace?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where are Thomas and Fedens?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I sent them home. Go and call them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I tried already. The phones do not work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Our great president is murdered, by the Tutsi cockroaches. They tricked him, then they killed him. We must cleanse this country, Good Hutus of Rwanda. We must clear the brush. Clear the brush of all cockroaches. Clear the brush!!!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Come on, everyone out of this room, find a seat in the living room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (in hushed anger) Is every Tutsi in the neighborhood here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They came through the bushes, over the wall. What could I do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Send them home. We are not the police. What do we have to protect them?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please. Let them stay 'til morning. The militia will not come here, they know you are a Hutu with influence.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They know you are Tutsi!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, Paul, 'til first light.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dawn. Then they go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forgive me, Paul. Danielle says that Roger has gone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gone where? Tell me, Danielle. Their daughter Danielle answers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Next door, mama. He was afraid for his friend Simon. He went to fetch him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Roger crawls between the shrubs.      He hears ANGRY VOICES. He peers through the long grass. Sees: Hutu soldiers boots, feet in sneakers, bare women's feet. And among them the glint of machetes, hoes, a club spiked with nails, a length of chain CLANGING on the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Tatiana rushes out the front door, Paul after her. Paul catches her and puts his hand over her mouth.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Shhhhh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: next door. Paul pulls Tatiana behind the car. A beat. More
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Paul takes his hand from her mouth. She's sobbing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NEIGHBOR'S YARD. NIGHT Roger crawls to the gap in the shrubs. Feet, a crowd, leaving, through a gate. Engines rev. Roger crawls from the bushes. Crawls across, the driveway, crawls through a puddle. Then stops, SEES SOMETHING, AN (UNSEEN) HORROR!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Paul and Tatiana exit the back of the house with flashlight in hand headed towards the rear gate. Paul searches along the chain link fence, finds a section loose, he pulls it back, clambers underneath it. Tatiana clasps her mouth, afraid to utter a cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then he hears BRANCHES SNAPPING. He moves toward the sound. Discovers Roger, terrified, thrashing in a tangle of bushes. He grabs Rogers shirt, pulls him as the little boy startles.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . NIGHT Paul crawls through this scrub tunnel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Ssshh! Paul drags his son through the chainlink fence, whisks him up in his arms and rushes him to the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Paul bursts through the back door and sets Roger down.   Tatiana is beside them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul turns the flashlight on Roger. Tatiana pulls back in horror: Roger is covered in blood. Her SCREAMS, stifled by fear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you hurt, son? oger stares blankly. Odette is beside them now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hands pull and tear his clothes off. Towels wipe him down. Odette looks all over his body with the flashlight. Despite the blood Roger has no injuries.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Roger, trembling, just stares, totally traumatized. Children cry.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #3 We need a room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I said everyone go over there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul approaches the BBC reporter Gloria and Colonel Oliver as their interview concludes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: COLONEL OLIVER Unfortunately we're here as peace-keepers not peace makers, we can't take an aggressive role.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Do we know who fired the missile that killed the president?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. But I fear it's intention may have been to kill the peace accords and spark a civil war between the Hutu Militia and the Tutsi rebels.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've heard reports of reprisal killings. Will the UN intervene to stop the bloodshed.?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: If the UN changes your mandate could you stop the bloodshed? COLONEL OLIVER Yes. With some re-inforcements I'm confident we could impose order. GLORIA Have you requested re-enforcements? COLONEL OLIVER Yes we have. GLORIA What was the response? COLONEL OLIVER We're awaiting a decision, excuse me. Colonel Oliver shakes Gloria's hand then moves off toward Paul. COLONEL OLIVER (CONT'D) Paul, I've sent my soldiers to rescue the Lady Prime Minister, she'll need a room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes sir, but these people (points) they cannot stay here. I've heard you have a refugee center at the airport Stadium? COLONEL OLIVER I'm sorry, I can't possibly take them Paul. I'm overrun with refugees. As soon as we can stabilize the situation we'll take them.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: moves to the door, where Jock and Gloria argue beside a saloon car with the word `press' spelt out in tape on the wind sreen
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She walks off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: For fuck's sake, Gloria There's a big news story out there! We need to get out and cover it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're not going outside the hotel grounds unless we have an armored car. That's the ground rules.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ground rules! Where the fuck do you think you are, Wimbledon?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We cover the story from here until we can get proper protection.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul works his way through the crowds in the lobby, sees a trolley of dishes by an elevator, looks around, can't see any staff. Disgusted, he pushes the trolley himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul pushes the trolley into the deserted kitchen. At the back door, several cooks listen to the radio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The cooks halfheartedly slouch back to the sinks.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: 'Good Hutus, we must destroy an infestation of cockroaches at the technical college.'
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Turn that off. We have a hotel to run.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT The lobby is overflowing with refugees. Paul stands with phone to ear. Zozo walks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Paul heads for the back office.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Zozo) Where's housekeeping? They won't pick up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir, no one wants to work. They say the boss has left.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT A neat corporate office. Paul picks up the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . BRUSSELS. NIGHT Several executive officers sit across from Sabena President GODEFROID around a speaker phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is really bad news. Paul can't allow them to close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: all our loyal customers. What would they think if Sabena deserted them now? (lies) I assure you the United Nations has everything under control.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Can I have your name again?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Paul Rusesabagina, Mr. Godefroid. The house manager. I met you on your last visit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, Paul, I remember. The Mille Collines is a very important property for Sabena. Our directors believe we should close down, shutter the place until this unrest is over?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir, that would be very bad for our reputation. We are an oasis of calm for
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: He looks at the others.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Very well. But if this thing gets worse, we must close. If there's anything you need, call anytime.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There is one thing I need right away.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Paul waits by the fax, then it spits out a single page.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Every member of the hotel staff is gathered together. Paul addresses them as Zozo hands out copies of a fax.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No one moves.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A hand goes up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: This is my letter of appointment, signed by Mr. Godefroid, the president of Sabena. The Mille Collines is a five star establishment, we will run it that way. If you don't want to work for me, then leave now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want the hallways cleaned now, a menu prepared for the dining room. Where's the pianist?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want you on the piano in the Kigali Room tonight. Back to work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . MORNING Paul emerges to find more refugees, some settled on the lawn, others gathered in clumps by the doorway. Paul calls over to the valet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Suddenly women and children on the lawn scream and run in fear. Behind them bushes shake, then suddenly a bloody figure wearing only boxer shorts bursts out from among the trees and flees to the middle of the driveway. It's the journalist, BENEDICT, covered in blood. His ear has been chopped off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Take these people to the rear car park, they can't stay here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: DEMONIUM. As Paul runs to him, calls to Zozo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Paul grabs Benedict, tries to calm him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He points down the driveway. This sparks many of the women refugees, and white guests, to flee inside the hotel. Odette arrives with her bag, leads Benedict inside. Jock has been filming all of this.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Get Odette!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What happened?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're killing everyone. The Lady Minister! The UN soldiers. They're at the gate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Now Jock runs, camera still on his shoulder, toward the gate. Paul takes off after him. More Tutsi refugees running up the driveway in fear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY As Jock films, Paul arrives by the gate house. UN soldiers watch the outside road. Engines roar, then. A convoy of Toyota trucks circle on the road outside the gate. Drunken Militia men on the back wave spears, machetes, one, in a woman's disco wig, waves a cordless power drill. The drill bit is red with blood. In the next truck, TWO Militia MEN triumphantly taunt the UN soldiers as they hold blue UN helmets high on sticks. The helmets are shot through with holes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: #1 We kill UN. We kill you next.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: cock their weapons, aim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: armored car races past the Militia and turns into the driveway. The back door opens, UN Colonel Oliver jumps out. COLONEL OLIVER Hold the line here. Do not shoot! The Colonel stabilizes the situation, his men watch the militia drive by. Paul approaches Oliver
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oliver shakes his head. He helps Paul clamber into the armored car.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's happening?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They murdered my soldiers. Ten Belgians who I sent to get the lady minister.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Where is she?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul follows Oliver as he marches through the lobby. Several reporters surround them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul watches the UN command disappear into an elevator.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Is it true about the Belgian soldiers... Are all ten dead?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul is in the corridor, talking to Tatiana. PAUL Has Roger spoken yet? TATIANA No, Odette says he's in shock. PAUL How can we help him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He needs to be in a safe place. (a beat) Have you heard from Mr. Garindi? PAUL Give him time. There's a clank of metal. Paul looks and sees: A waiter struggling with a trolley of food by a door. He hurries to help the waiter as Jock opens, indicates quiet, waves Paul and the waiter in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY The room is set up as a make-shift broadcast center. Gloria is on a phone to the BBC in London, she hangs up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She fixes her outfit, sits straight up in the chair. Behind her two monitors show footage of a plane crash and bodies along roads.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gloria on the phone, listens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jock turns to Paul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jock points skyward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She hangs up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jock's is at the window scanning with his camera, getting b roll, then he sees something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jock's filming as Peter makes the connection.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jock focuses On the monitor: blurry focus of a shanty town on a hill.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, we're feeding through live now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay London .... and five four three two one ...That's correct Tom. Today's gruesome ambush of a ten man Belgian patrol has left the UN peacekeeping force in a state of disarray. Its commander has called for re-enforcements. However, the General Council is deeply divided. The United States, still smarting from the UN's disastrous Somalia mission, has indicated that it will veto any moves to reinforce. Meanwhile, the slaughter goes on. Gloria Brooks in Kigali, Rwanda.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And, cut ...good, give me a call guys, let me know you've got it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perfect timing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This goes out live?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Satellite feed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Great. (listens) No kidding,  When will they be here? Excellent. Yes, call then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The news room has heard that the French and the Belgians are putting together an intervention force.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When will they be here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Very soon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey Peter, hook me back into the monitors.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Holy shit! Holy shit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : Of a crowd hovering close to a group of Rwandan Tutsis seated on the ground. Two Militia emerge from the crowd, waving machetes. They SLASH their way along the line, savage, powerful blows, butchering people like cattle.          (Author note: we will use real news footage of this)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On Screen: The crowd run off, waving machetes. Gloria snaps out of her shock, snatches the phone, dials.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She puts the phone down, turns to the others, triumphant. An embarrassed silence in the room. Jock is disgusted by her glee. He picks up a plate from the trolley.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She storms out. Paul fills the embarrassed silence.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You fucking see that!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shock) Oh my God!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's Gloria. Listen we've footage, unbelievable footage! A massacre! Machetes, murderers, dead bodies. You have to lead with this. We'll send it through right now. Wait 'til you see this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Gloria) Here, have a sandwich.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fuck you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm glad you filmed this. Now the West will have to stop it. Excuse me, gentlemen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . EVENING The businessman Mr. Garindi knocks on room 211. Paul opens the door, sees him, then turns back to Tatiana.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tatsi appears at the door with several of the kids.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The kids do as they're told. Paul and Tatsi shut the door and join the businessman in the hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tatiana clings to Paul, fearful of the news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The businessman shakes his head no. Tears run down Tatiana's face. She holds Paul's arm to stop from falling to the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul takes a small wad of notes from his pocket, presses it into the businessman's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He leaves. Tatiana pulls Paul to her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Tatsi, come.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the kids) Go back inside.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you find the twins?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GARINDI I made it to the house but it was empty. It had been robbed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Was there blood?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GARINDI No blood. As I left a neighbor, an old woman, waved to me. I went to her house. She has the little girls. They are safe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My brother, his wife. Did this woman know of them? Did they leave the children with her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is not bad news, Tatsi. Perhaps they fled or could not make it home. There is hope.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the businessman) Please go back, bring the children to us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GARINDI (frightened)No ma'am, I cannot do that. The roadblocks are everywhere. They are looking for children. They shout, "Kill the babies to clear the infestation." Leave them be, they are safe. I have to go now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you for your help.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My sister is dead, Paul. They would not leave the children.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. They are not dead. Stop this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul and Tatiana push through the French tourists and AID workers running across the lobby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cheers break out. Paul and Tatsi peer from the crowd and through the lobby window see:
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mon Dieu, Merci.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY French and Italian special forces pull into the parking lot, standing tall in their jeeps, macho western super troops, triumphant. Salvation!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Wild cheering, flowers draped around necks, kisses. Westerners, Rwandans, dance and sing in celebration. Paul SEES: Colonel Oliver off to the side, with the commanders of the French special forces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ON:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have a battalion, you could stop this now. The Hutu army is no match for you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oliver pulls off his blue beret, throws it on the ground, points his finger at the French and Italian officers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks off, returns, picks up his beret. Paul watches as he storms into the lobby. Paul follows.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Those are not our orders.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You will remember this day for the rest of your lives.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul follows the Colonel into the Kigali Club. The place is empty, the bartender missing, gone to celebrate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oliver cracks a weary smile. Paul pours two drinks, slides one across. He raises his glass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Colonel, what can I get you? Paul gets behind the bar.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anything. Strong.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Canadian Club?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Congratulations, Colonel. You have saved us all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (raw cynicism) Congratulations. You should spit in my face.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, Colonel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We think you are dirt, less than dirt, worthless.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't understand.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't bullshit me, Paul. You're the smartest man here. You have them all eating out of your hand. You'd own this fucking hotel, except for one thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're fucking black! You're not even a nigger, you're African! (downs his drink) They're not staying to stop this thing. They're gonna fly right out of here with their people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (shocked) Their people?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They're only taking the whites.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul opens the door. Tatiana and the kids pack bags, prepare to leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tatiana and the children stop what they're doing, puzzled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The kids leave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul takes her hands in his.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tatiana's grip tightens.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tatiana clings to hope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul looses it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . He looks up at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He takes her hand, makes her sit down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tatiana's eyes are wide with fear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul takes his anger out on Tatiana.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He storms out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Children, go into the hallway.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the kids) Please, go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All the whites are leaving.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They are being evacuated.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about us?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We have been abandoned.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The soldiers will stop the killers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Listen to me woman. I said all the whites are leaving. The French, the Italians, even the Belgian UN soldiers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But who is left?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. Colonel Oliver says the UN has three hundred soldiers for the whole country. Black soldiers, Pakistanis.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The most the Colonel can spare for the hotel are four men, and they're not allowed to shoot.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If anything should happen, if the Militia arrive, you must take the children and go to the roof.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do what I say, woman. You hear me? I will meet you there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY REVEAL: A chaos of luggage, white tourists, AID agency people, Italian and French soldiers, elite, slick. On the edges, clumps of Rwandans, watching, silent, fearful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY A torrential African rain storm soaks everything. Porters with big umbrellas run the white evacuees to the buses. French and Italian commanders check off names on clipboards. Jock films the evacuees boarding buses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY At the front desk, Paul, dripping wet from working the convoy,    listens to a French tourist who refuses to pay his bill.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul, stone-faced, polite, destroys this asshole.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why should I pay to stay in a, in a holocaust? Tell me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are not staying sir, you are leaving.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul watches in the rain as the final agency people are being loaded onto buses. Several white aid workers weep uncontrollably as they are dragged away from frightened Rwandan coworkers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in the rain. cross the parking lot Colonel Oliver watches from his jeep. Jock and his sound man embrace two beautiful young HOOKERS. One girl begs Jock to take her with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He digs in his pockets, pulls out money, cigarettes. Everything he has he gives to her. Then he pulls her toward Paul, digs out his wallet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pushes two Visa cards into Paul's hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jock pulls a Rolex off his wrist. PAUL This is a Rolex, I can't take it. JOCK Take it for Christ sake. I wish it was a fucking aeroplane. Jock embraces Paul, tears in his eyes. Gloria watches from the doorway. Embarrassed by Jock, She becomes officious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gloria marches onto the bus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jock kisses the hooker, heaves his camera onto the bus. Then there is a disturbance on the driveway. A group of French nuns, along with maybe a hundred Tutsi women and children come running up the driveway. They are all terrified. One nun leads them with a French flag. French soldiers run forward.
