A commander orders them to form   a line, blocking the refugees. French soldiers begin pulling nuns from the terrified crowd. Several nuns begin hysterically weeping, pulling Rwandan children with them. Panic breaks out among the crowd.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Please, please, they will put me on the street. They will chop me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Darlin', believe me, if I could...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here. Here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give her what she wants, room, food, anything. Charge it all. Don't you put her out, Paul.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I would never do that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know that, Paul. I'm sorry. Here take this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's go, Jock.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turns on her) Go! What the fuck sort of journalists are we, running from a war? I'm ashamed. Are you? Well, are ya'?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're drunk.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to a French soldier) What are we waiting for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We have to evacuate some nuns from a convent. They are on their way.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BUS. DAY Jock grabs his camera, pushes off the bus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Nuns cling to young children. French soldiers wrench the nuns away, lift them off their feet, carry them to the bus.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: films, as A FRENCH OFFICER screams at him. The last nun is dragged onto a bus. Jock looks to Paul, then gets on the bus. The convoy - French jeeps, buses, Italian jeeps, UN jeeps takes off, through the refugees, turns a corner, gone. Paul, drenched, is left alone to fend for his new guests: Weeping women, frightened children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY The convoy passes the gate house. Across the road, two jeeps of Rwandan Army soldiers watch the convoy leave. They get on the radio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Where five minutes before the lobby was a frenzy of wealthy Europeans and aid workers, the groups of clustered black faces are silent except for the crying of babies and sobbing mothers. Paul picks his way among them. Zozo catches up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What do we do with all these people?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Open up the ballroom, we'll put them there. And Zozo tell the kitchen to make rice and beans - a lot of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY. Paul enters, drops to the bed. Tatiana curls up next to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul puts on his walkman earphones, presses play, the rich cowboy drawl of Don Williams singing ??? Close on: Paul as his eyes droop and to the music. A kalidiscope of colors filter through drooping eyelids as Close on Paul's face, as the music plays. His eyes open wide, disturbed, music playing Paul's POV, an Army lieutenant stands over him, other soldiers around. The lieutenant reaches down, pulls the earphones from Paul's ears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The lieutenant is not impressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Cold drinks' softens the soldiers' attitudes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The soldiers march off. Paul goes back inside. The kids, sensing the menace, sit still and wide-eyed on the floor. Suddenly Tatiana notices Roger is missing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where's Roger? Danielle points to under the bed. CLOSE ON: Roger trembling under the bed, as Paul's face appears. PAUL Come on son, everything is all right. He slides him out, clutches him in his arms, then turns him over to Tatiana as he phones the front desk. PAUL (CONT'D) (on phone) Who is this? Zozo. I know. Get them beer. He turns to Tatiana.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hurries out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You could leave, Paul.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you saying, Tatsi?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your card says Hutu. Take our children, go and get the twins, pay money at the roadblocks. Get them out. Please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Enough of this. We stay together. Let me rest, I will feel better then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are the manager?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir. What is wrong?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everyone must leave the hotel now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's an order. Get everyone out now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...ah...need some time. Please give us twenty, thirty minutes. People are sleeping.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, have some cold drinks. I will be as quick as I can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We will be outside, ten minutes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go to the roof now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (terrified) What for Paul.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (forceful) Do as I say. I will be there soon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul's door opens, his head appears round the corner. The corridor is empty of soldiers. Now, frightened Tutsis peer out from their rooms. A group of men, among them the politician Xavier, are gathered in the hallway. Paul spots one man holding a pistol. He runs up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul pulls the gun off him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul hands the gun to Xavier, hurries off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to the man with the pistol) Are you mad? They will gun us all down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Better to die by the bullet than the machete.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wait here, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul bursts in, sits by the phone and dials.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Phone again.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good day, General Bizimungu please. Do you know where he is? Please ask him to call Paul Rusesabagina. It is urgent.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : increasingly frantic calls.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Colonel Bagsora. Where? Can you find him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who would order such a thing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Paul hangs up the phone defeated. He looks at his watch. His head flops onto the desk, onto the Sabena logo. He sees it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Did you find the General?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY The Sabena president and two VPs sit on couches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His intercom buzzes, he's annoyed then.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The president goes to the phone, hits the speaker button.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The president is baffled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The president can barely form words to reply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hits the hold button. Looks to the other executives. They are stunned to silence by Paul's profound farewell.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: If British Airways abandons the route we should bid for it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, sir. I have a call from Paul in Kigali. He says it's urgent.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Paul. Are you alright?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) We have a big problem. The Hutu army have come and ordered us all of us out of the hotel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Out? Where are you going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I do not know, sir. I think they will kill us all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All. What do you mean all?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The staff, the guests.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The staff and guests! How many?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now we have eight hundred guests and one hundred staff. I have ten minutes left. I wish I could have done more, sir. Please, thank all my friends at Sabena. You have been good to me and my family.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (panicked) Paul, wait, wait, I'm going to put you on hold for one minute, stay on the phone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul listens to music on the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Pandemonium - the president has everyone working the phones.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Get the prime minister's office. Call General Chareaux. Louis get the UN. Tell them this is Belgian property.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY The music is suddenly interrupted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul thinks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul hurries from the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Paul, are you there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, thank you Mr. President.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Paul, if you have one call in all the world to stop this, who would you call?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The French. They supply the Rwandan army.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Paul, do everything you can to buy time. I will call you back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Zozo at the computer, printing something. Paul walks up, sees: The Hotel's Registry printing. Paul grabs it, studies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He pushes Zozo toward the elevator.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now Paul is on the computer, typing.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What are you doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The lieutenant wants the register.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go and get more beer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : The register shows that day's date: April 13. Paul hits a few keys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : The date above the register is April 4. Paul hits the print button. The printer clicks to life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul with the printed registry and Zozo with beer walk to the jeeps. The soldiers don't wait for the Captain's order, they mob Zozo, grab beers. The lieutenant marches up to Paul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul hands him the printout. He studies it, reads.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The lieutenant grabs Paul by the shirt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul turns to walk back in. The lieutenant hurries to his men, pulls beers from their hands, smashes them on the ground. One soldier comes running to him with a radio. Paul watches. The lieutenant listens, then calls to Paul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul returns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The soldiers roar off down the driveway.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where's the guest list?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anderson, Arthurs, Boulier. What is this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The guest list. It hasn't been updated since the murder of the president.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are you trying to make a fool of me? There are no Europeans left in that hotel. Get me the names of all the cockroaches in there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That will take time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't have time. If I do not have the names, so that I can pick out the traitors, then I will kill everyone here in this car park. Get in there now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey you, come here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who did you call?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Call, sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't lie to me. What's your name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rusesabagina. Paul Rusesabagina.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will remember that name. (turns to his soldiers) Let's go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: looks to Paul, a thank you Jesus look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul emerges onto the roof, sees Tatiana, his children, and many of the neighbors sitting huddled together. (They do not know the soldiers have left.) Tatiana is frozen to the spot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tatiana grabs him. Tears of joy. Paul's neighbors swarm him, touch him, thank him like a messiah. This effects him. He seems genuinely moved as he shakes hands and hugs them.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They have gone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir. The president of Sabena is on the phone for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul arrives behind the front desk. Paul hits the button.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They are gone. Thank you, sir. What did you do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . BRUSSELS. DAY Gotfroid is at his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I managed to get the President of France on the phone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Thank you, sir, you saved our lives.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Paul, I pleaded with the president to go in and get you all. He told me it will not happen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can give you many political answers Paul but the truth is that Africa is not worth a single vote to all of them: French, British, Americans.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have to get out of there, Paul. I will do whatever I can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY The elite of the Tutsi refugees, those with contacts or friends abroad, are gathered in the office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The others look stunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul leaves.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There will be no rescue, no intervention force. We can only save ourselves. Call any foreigner you know, tell them what will happen to us. Say goodbye but when you say goodbye, say it as though you're reaching through and shaking their hand. Let them know if they let go of that hand, you will die. (silence) We must shame them into sending help.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get on the phones while we still can. At least we can say they heard our cries. Zozo come with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul looks around the lobby. It resembles a refugee center more than a five star hotel. He turns to a computer, calls up the register, then hits DELETE and erases the register. He picks up the phone, calls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul strides across the lobby, calls to Zozo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They herd together quickly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: About fifty percent of the hands go up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The carpenters arrive beside Paul.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Send two of the housekeeping carpenters to the lobby.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everyone gather together now. Zozo get them all together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No one can remain in this lobby any longer. I have rooms available. Who can pay? The rental is six hundred francs per day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I cannot pay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go with Zozo to the ballroom. We will find you bedding. This is a hotel. No one will be allowed to stay in the lobby.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good. I want you to go around and take all the numbers off the doors.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What shall we put in their place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing. I want no numbers on the doors.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul going door to door, knocking. The rooms are all packed with Tutsi refugees. A door opens.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good day. Here is your bill for the last week. If you cannot pay, or think you will not be able to pay, go to the ballroom. Zozo will take care of you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY. Paul knocks on a door. The Tutsi politician Xavier opens the door, sees that it is Paul.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Come in Paul.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY A beautiful two-bedroom suite. Xavier lives in comfort compared to the other refugees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul leaves, Xavier looks shocked.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm afraid you will have to move room.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Move? Where to?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm going to put you on the third floor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The third floor are low class rooms.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes they are. However if the army return they will expect important people such as yourself to be in these grand rooms.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to his wife) Pack the bags, we have to move.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Also, this is your bill for the last week.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Paul and influential refugees, Odette, Benedict (with a bandage over his missing ear), Xavier and others call, plead, write and send faxes all around the world. We see this NIGHT and DAY; DAY and NIGHT -- hen Odette on the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Zozo arrives.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, that's right. I helped set up the treatment center in Nairobi. I'm in the Mille Collines Hotel right now with my husband, Peter, and my two boys. If you do not help us we will be murdered.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir, General Bizimungu is here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY The pool patio is deserted except for General Bizimungu and three soldiers who lounge at a table. Gregoire and his girlfriend sun on reclining deck chairs like movie stars. Paul and a waiter with a tray of drinks join the General.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul hands the scotch to Bizimungu.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul points surreptitiously to the sky. The General looks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The General looks again to the sky then.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I am glad you are well.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry it is not Glenmorangie.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As long as it is scotch. (drinks) Your white friends have abandoned you, Paul.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The United Nations are still here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughs) The United Nations. Madmen are on the streets, Paul. But I will take care of you. (chugs his drink) Your cellar is well-stocked, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, General. I am glad you came by. I overheard something that I think you should know about.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did you overhear?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A discussion between an American Embassy official and a UN Colonel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did they say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The American assured the colonel that they would watch everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Watch everything? How? They are gone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Satellites.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Satellites?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, they can photograph the epaulets on your shoulder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And what will they do with these satellites?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The American said intervention is too costly, better to get photographic evidence and snatch up the high command.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The high command? Our high command?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: 'Snatch them up and put on a war crimes trial. Lock them all away forever. No political risk, and big publicity.' That's what he said. (a beat) I thought I'd better tell you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Americans! Who are they to put us on trial. Let us imagine Paul when their president Kennedy was shot, they said it was a black man. Then their politicians, their radio stations gave orders `we must wipe out these black people before they wipe out us.' What do you think would have happened? No different.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Indeed, general. Excuse me momentarily.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul fills Bizimungu's briefcase with scotch, hands two six-packs of beer to Zozo. Paul notes his once packed storeroom, now considerably dwindled in stock.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where has all our beer gone?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir, Gregoire has been taking beers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How much beer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Many beers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . AFTERNOON Paul arrives back at the pool, hands Bizimungu his briefcase. Zozo gives the beer to the soldiers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: "Well rewarded" Those were his words. GENERAL BIZIMUNGU If I were to spare a few policemen, where would I station them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul nods over toward Gregoire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: he General gets up. Gregoire, who is lying face down on the deck chair, doesn't see him approach. The General pulls the deck chair from underneath Gregoire and throws it into the pool. As Gregoire tries to scramble to his feet, the General propels him forward with a massive kick up the ass.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gregoire races from the pool, followed by his girlfriend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The General clicks his fingers and his soldiers follow.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I am worried about thieves and criminals coming into the hotel. Perhaps you could arrange for some police to guard us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The police are very busy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I understand General, but when I last talked to the president of Sabena he promised me that anyone who helped protect Belgian property would be rewarded. Bizimungu understands this is a financial proposition.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The front gate would be best, General. They could check all guests.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will see what I can do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I admire you, General. How do you keep command of your men amidst such madness?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I am strong, Paul, like a lion.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wish I were like you. Look at my staff, they won't work, they listen to no one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He is staff?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get to work, you slug.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Make sure, Paul, your guests are generous.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Benedict greets Paul in the lobby.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Paul, we would like to speak to you in your office.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We, who is we?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A delegation.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul walks in and discovers the office packed with the elite Tutsi refugees including Xavier, Odette and Jean Baptiste. Paul's puzzled, there's an air of tension in the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A brief silence, then a Tutsi bank manager speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another accuser speaks up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Murmurs of agreement. Paul has heard enough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have no right to charge us rent.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is no longer a hotel, it is a prison and you are profiteering from our misery.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That is not true.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes it is. He charges for food, for everything. Where is all this money going? We hear he has a deal with Bizimungu.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #2 It is said that you work for the murderer George Rutagunda.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I confess. ( a beat) It's true I have a deal with General Bizimungu. He was just here. I worked out another money making scheme for him. New arrivals will be taxed at the gate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know what my deal is with Bizimungu. I pay him and he keeps you alive. Anyone want to take their money back?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: pulls money from his pocket, hands it around, offers it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks among them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul holds the door open.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They hurry out, duly chastised. But Odette and her husband Jean Baptiste remain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul hasn't got an answer for that one. He leads them out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Here, here take it. And you don't have to pay your bill. I will move you into the ballroom or out into the gardens.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And, yes, I work with George Rutagunda. I buy rice and beans, beer and soap. I will have to visit his warehouse soon because we are running out of food. Who wants to come with me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Anyone who wants to come with me stay behind. If not, please leave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (laughs) You are most certainly not coming with me. You will get me killed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You can't go to that place, they know what you are doing here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: George will not hurt me, I am too profitable to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What if he is not there?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Roger is asleep, on a couch in the living room, several kids sleep on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Where Tatiana suppresses bursts of laughter as Paul relates the Gregoire story in whispers.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: As soon as the General left he came running back. (mimics Gregoire) Help me, sir, I have been possessed by a witch. (Paul's own voice now) A witch you say? (mimics) Yes, yes, I did not know I was in that room. The president's room, why would I be in the president's room? (own voice) Indeed, the General asked me the same. (mimics) Asked you what? (own voice) Does Gregoire think he is president now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: mimics Gregoire's whimpers of fear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul lifts the bottle of fine bordeaux, pours more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They both chuckle, then Paul remembers, a cloud of anxiety comes over him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She kisses him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She kisses him again, tries to cheer him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (laughing) Stop, stop, we will waken the children.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lynch Bages, 84. Perfect with lamb, or fine rare beef.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So where is the lamb?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe Gregoire and the witch ate it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's the matter?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We're running out of beer and other supplies.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The foreigners abandon us and you do inventory. You are so conscientious.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have to go out to get food.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Go out! Where?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To Rutagunda's place. It is close by.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, no.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have to, Tatiana, we are only as valuable as the service we provide.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You cannot go alone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not going alone. I'll take Gregoire with me. He's a good Hutu, and he wants to impress me now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY The lobby is deserted except for Gregoire now neatly dressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gregoire nods, impressed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: regoire it is good to see you back to work.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, except my humblest apologies...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry. I have a job this morning. I must go to visit my good friend George Rutagunda. You know George?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fetch the van.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAWN A thick mist blankets the grounds as Paul and Gregoire emerge.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (fearful) Where are we going, sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: For supplies, you drive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The fog is too heavy, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just drive, Gregoire.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAWN They pass the gate, the policemen are asleep in the box. The van passes along the deserted main road, past a wrecked car, over broken glass, the fog swirls around them. Then Gregoire hits the brakes. In front of them, a makeshift barricade, long poles stretched across two oil drums. They wait for someone to appear from the fog: No one.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul wants to agree, but can't. He opens his door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We should go back, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul gets out, tentative.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing. He moves to the barrier, lifts the pole, places it on the ground, hurries back to the van.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hello?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAWN PAUL Let's go. They drive past the barricade. The van weaves through the fog-enshrouded streets. hey slow to check road signs in the fog - on one a woman's dress, shredded and soaked in blood, is draped like a banner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAWN The fog still hangs like a cloud. As they pull up, a group of young Militia emerge from Toyota trucks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul and Gregoire hand over their ID cards. The Militia man studies them, then pockets the cards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then from out of the fog, three Toyota trucks roar up. George Rutagunda, heavily armed, in cut-off shorts and an open shirt, his barrel chest laden with bandoliers, jumps out. he Militia man pulls out the ID cards, hands them back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rutagunda strides over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul climbs out, greets George, as a Militia man swings open the doors of the warehouse. They walk in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: #1 What do you want?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We are to meet Mr. Rutagunda.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 The commander is not here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He will be here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 Show me your ID
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Our cards, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 What cards?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have our cards.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 No. But I make cards. Would you like me to make you two cards?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How much?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 One thousand francs.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 (CONT'D) apologetic) joke.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Paul. My old friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY The warehouse is filled with looted televisions, artwork, cars. George points to the stacks of beer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul counts out the Rwandan francs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul's stomach heaves. He hides it, turns over the money, gets in the van with Gregoire. George comes to the passenger window.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Everything is double the price now, you do understand that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I need rice, beans, beer, and your best whiskey.    G EORGE Beer yes, but no whiskey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have no whiskey?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No whiskey, no spirits. Your rich cockroaches at the hotel, they will have to do without their scotch. Anyway, I have bled that cow enough Paul.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean George?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Their money is no good to them. Soon all the Ineysi will be dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (incredulous) ) You cannot kill them all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not? We are half way there already.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Let me give you a tip my friend, our generals in the army say 'do not go near the Mille Collines or they will send the Belgian soldiers back here'. But the generals are about to leave, and we will be in charge. It is time to butcher your cow for the meat. (a beat) You can help us Paul. You have some very important traitors at your hotel. The politician Xavier. The liar Benedict. If we were to get them, then maybe we could let one or two cockroaches get away. You understand, Paul. Paul says nothing, but Gregoire has been listening very carefully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The van takes off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let's go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take the river road back. It is clear.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAWN The fog has gotten thicker. They can barely see a yard ahead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The van begins to bump erratically. Bump, bump, bump.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The van jerks to a halt.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Are you sure this is the river road?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I saw the sign.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stop. You've driven off the road. You'll put us in the river.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAWN Paul clambers out, stumbles, falls. And discovers he's looking at the face of a dead child, a young Tutsi girl, her hands clasped on her ears as though to block the sound of her own death - an African Munz's Scream. Paul clambers to his feet, sees that the van is on a road littered with dead bodies, men, women, children. he bumps were dead bodies, the van has driven over them. A breeze from the lake blows the fog clear for thirty feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : a carpet of bodies, hundreds of them sprawled all along the road as far as Paul can see. Paul wanders stunned among misshapen corpses, made more ghostly by wisps of fog. Finally, Paul clambers shell-shocked back into the van.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gregoire throws the van into reverse. hey bump back over the carpet of bodies, each shake and crunch another horror.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Go back! Go back!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY The van pulls up at the rear suppliers entrance. Paul hops out, turns to Gregoire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gregoire, Zozo and the porters begin unloading the van.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Tell no one what you saw, do you understand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul wanders to a bench set back in a manicured grove of bushes. Beyond him a crowd of Rwandan refugee children play in the swimming pool, laughing, jumping, splashing like they were at a municipal pool in Central Park.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: watches. Tears stream from his eyes, the stream grows into a flood, he buries his face in his hands. Then a voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul wipes his eyes, turns. A little boy stands behind him, holding out his arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then Paul sees what is wrong. The boy Has a big thorn imbedded in the muscle of his arm. Paul studies it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul pulls on the thorn, the kid doesn't flinch. Paul picks him up, carries him to the pool, throws him in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) Mr. Manager.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Mr. Manager, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's a big one. (pinches the thorn) Here we go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Tatiana feeds the children - rice and beans. Paul arrives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Roger tries to speak, struggles to mouth the words but nothing comes out, as though he has forgotten. Tears form in his eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hugs him, puts him back at his food, then takes Tatiana's hand, leads her to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They slip out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good evening, Papa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Roger, you have no greeting for me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There, do not worry, no tears.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whispers) Where are we going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Tatiana stops.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Please, Paul, why do we have to go to the roof?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's alright. This is the only place I can find some peace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Paul slips out onto the roof. Tatiana follows. Artillery and mortar fire rumble in the distance. Flashes silhouette along the far hills above Kigali. He leads her to a blanket, a candle, two glasses and the bottle of wine. They sit. He opens the wine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They kiss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: he kisses him again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: he slaps him playfully.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She kisses him, they lie back on the roof, kiss passionately.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (laughs) I hear we must pay for everything. How much for this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A kiss.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are a very good man, Paul Rusesabagina.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have a confession. When we met...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In Ruhengeri?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, when you worked as the nurse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I had you transferred to Kigali.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I bribed the Minister of Health to have you transferred to Kigali.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To be closer. So that I could marry you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What was the bribe? (silence) What am I worth to you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It was substantial.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tell me what it was.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A car.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What sort of car?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What does it matter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I want to know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Volkswagen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Volkswagen!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I hope it was a new Volkswagen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul instructs the porters to clean around the entrance. The UN armored car comes up the driveway. Colonel Oliver gets out, strides across the tarmac, he shakes Paul's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I The sweetest words Paul has ever heard.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Great news, Paul, we're going to get you out of here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Oliver is on the stage, all the refugee guests are crowded into the room he has a list in his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He reads.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Abukesu - Tanzania, Arumangu -Zambia, Bawroanga - Kenya,
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: The UN has been notified that the following families have received travel visas from the following countries.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ON: Elation among the chosen families.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Gituaranga - Zambi, Horangora - Belguim
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ON - Fear on the faces of families who realize they have missed this alphabetical list, anxiety among the others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tatiana kisses Paul.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: voice calls out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oliver jumps from the stage, pushes through the crowd. Paul's POV: Odette and Jean Baptiste are silently devastated. He pushes through to the Colonel now surrounded by those who didn't make the list.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oliver shakes his head no.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul nods yes. Tatiana arrives beside him, pulls him aside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She reluctantly nods yes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Paramisambi - Zambia, Rusesabagina - Belgium.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Zamacanga - Ghana. A plane will land at the airport tomorrow and the named families will be flown to Kenya. Two UN trucks will be here at 7 a.m. The named families must be ready to leave then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Colonel, sir. Why not take us all to the airport? We can wait there to obtain visas.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I can't do that. Our camp at the airport is overwhelmed already. We could not defend you there. You are better to stay here and work to get an exit visa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Colonel, Odette Camundu ... she must be on the list.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Paul, only those I called can get on the trucks. I do not want to have to pull people off, you understand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will not leave without the twins.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We have to get out of here Tatiana.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, please try one more time.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll try but we have to leave, with or without them. I want you to promise.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Mr. Garindi waits nervously in the lobby. Paul arrives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The businessman turns back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul spots an elegant woman carrying laundry toward the elevator. He runs to her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: . GARINDI It is dangerous to be here. The radio says this is a nest of cockroaches.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I need one last favor. Go back and get the twins.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GARINDI (emphatic) No, it is impossible. That side of town has been destroyed in the fighting. The children are dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How do you know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . GARINDI Everyone is dead there. The dogs eat the bodies in the street. I have to go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will give you my house.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a fine house. Here is a paper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Madame Kawunda, please. Paul leads her over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul signs, then hands the pen to the puzzled woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She signs. Paul pushes the deed into the man's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . The businessman heads for the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul watches him go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Mr. Garindi leaves.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I need you to witness this signature. (to the businessman) Madame Kawunda is the Minister for Agriculture. She is a very reliable witness.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please witness this deed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There, now go and find them. They have no papers. No one knows they are Tutsi. They will be alive.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You must be back by 7:00a.m. tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Seven, remember.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT Paul skirts the little groups of poor families bivouacked on the lawn. The smoke of cooking fires has replaced the Tiki lanterns. The grounds are a mini refugee camp. Paul joins Tatiana, Odette and Jean Baptiste who sit at a table by the pool.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry, Paul, we will make the next list.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: arrives, with beers, serves them, is about to leave. Tatiana grabs him by the arm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sit with us Zozo. ZOZO No ma,am, I am too busy. PAUL Zozo you are family, join us. Zozo is shocked by this breach of protocol but sits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He embraces Jean Baptiste
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Odette hugs and kisses him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul takes Zozo in his arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A unbreakable bond of faith with each other.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You are my dearest friends. I promise you before God that I will not sleep until I have you out of here. All of you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It is good that you are going, Paul, because now we know we have one person who will save us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We owe you our lives.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You are my family now, Zozo, my brother. I will get you out of here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let us remember this night and tell the world that even in hell there are good people.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY The lucky families are gathered: Tatiana and all her children; Xavier and his wife; Benedict; and others. Some of the unlucky ones peer around the door of the ballroom. A UN officer stands in their way.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Back. Everyone back. Only those with letters of acceptance in the lobby.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY The UN convoy waits outside.   Tatiana waits nervously as Paul   checks his watch.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: A little longer, Paul?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We wait until 7:00. If he is not here with the twins he is not coming. We leave. That was your promise. Go help the children.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul is in a horrible mood. The refugees in the ballroom try to push by the UN officer. Paul joins him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Zozo scampers off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul herds the convoy people toward the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Back, please. Stay back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Zozo, tell those people to get back to the ballroom. They can not be here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are we waiting for? Come on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ON: Gregoire watching from behind the front desk. Through the doors we see the trucks being loaded. Zozo returns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Reluctant, Paul walks over to the ballroom dwellers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul reaches out for the letters, takes them, reads the addresses: President Nelson Mandela. Pope John Paul. President Clinton.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Zozo hands Paul the letter. He studies the address. It reads "To the great man Muhammad Ali." thers crowd around.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul's at a loss. He has to tear himself away. fraid to look back, he heads for the convoy.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Sir, the others want to speak to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good, sir we have letters, please take them for us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: #1 If you leave, we are certain to die.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have a letter, sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will get you all visas. I promise. I will get you out of here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY The last of the evacuees clamber onto the UN trucks. The children are on board but Tatiana waits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He checks his watch, then takes her in his arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul helps Tatiana on board. He looks toward the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ask them to wait a little longer. For the twins.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Get on the truck, Tatiana.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Look, our children are crying, please get on the truck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : The unlucky refugees are now crowded at the windows, lost souls watching out from their prison at the lucky ones. Paul whispers to Benedict as he boards.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . TRUCK DAY Paul clambers on beside him.   He reaches Tatiana as Benedict sits beside her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul backs off. Tatiana tries to follow. Benedict grabs her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A commotion as she tries to get up.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I have to stay.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No! Sit down now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I cannot leave these people. I will wait for the twins.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let go. Let me off this truck.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me go. Children get off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I will follow on the next plane. Go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY. The truck starts up. Paul runs beside it, shouts to Tatiana.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then another voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The convoy takes off down the driveway. Paul, Zozo and other refugees cluster by the door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I love you. Keep the children safe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Paul!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Papa! Papa!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: looks round, I Sees: Gregoire put a phone down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY UN Colonel Oliver sits next to a UN PAKISTANI DRIVER. he convoy passes looters and small groups of Militia on the road but proceeds unheeded.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY The room is still littered with clothes, kids drawings, the personal junk accumulated over four weeks. Paul tries to arrange things, then collapses on the bed, paralysed with doubt - Why did he do this? Then the door bangs.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Boss, sir, quick, please, come quick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY The door springs open, Paul confronts Zozo.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (breathless) Sir, the radio, you must hear, it is on the radio.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul and Zozo burst into the kitchen. The cooks and others are clustered, listening to the radio.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) ...Block the roads to the airport! The cockroaches from the Mille Collines are escaping! Xavier. The liar Benedict, the traitor Rusesabagina's cockroaches. Stop them now at Rue Don Bosco. Thirty thousand francs for the head of Xavier!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dear lord, how did they know?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I saw Gregoire make a call, sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As the trucks go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul bursts out of the kitchen - enraged. Gregoire is at the front desk. Sees Paul - understands instantly. Gregoire takes off, running for his life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul chases after him, through the door. Gregoire disappears into the thicket of trees. Paul after him. Through the trees. Gregoire, younger, faster, climbs the high wire fence. Finally, Paul reaches the fence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Sees Gregoire escape into the bushes on the other side of the fence. Paul gives up, turns back toward the hotel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY As the UN jeep turns a bend, Colonel Oliver SEES crowds of Interahamwe swarming from beside houses, from gardens. They pull burning tires, old furniture, junk onto the road.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY The UN truck suddenly lurches, then slows.    The refugees from the Mille Collines grow alarmed.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's happening?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul is on the fax phone, begging.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Please, General, I will give you money, whiskey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (O.S.) You said you had no whiskey.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Please, I have money. They're driving into an ambush, it's on the radio.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Swarms of crazed Militia fill the road. Gun fire breaks out. Colonel Oliver steps from the jeep, waving his pistol in the air. M ilitia men swarm around him, push past to the truck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: through the canvas. hildren scream, HANDS GRAB at people. Benedict is hauled off the truck. Beaten. Tatiana protects her kids in a corner, kicking at the hands that grab for her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Xavier falls to the ground. Screams, shouts, MORE SHOTS. Oliver fights his way through to Xavier. Oliver points his pistol. The crowd backs off slightly. Xavier gets to his feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - more gun fire. IMMACULATA falls, wounded in the foot. More are dragged from the trucks. Machetes flash in the sun. Then HORNS, GUNFIRE - RWANDAN SOLDIERS drive through the crowd in two jeeps. The crowd scatters, then re-forms as Rwandan soldiers push between the Militia and the refugees. As they do, another Militia gunman steps out, fires wildly at the refugees, but wounds A RWANDAN SOLDIER in the stomach. Suddenly fights erupt between the Militia and the soldiers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul paces up and down, he can hear gunfire in the distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - THEN SINGLE SHOTS. Paul jumps in the van, guns the engine, drives.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. Paul's van speeds toward the gate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - A LOUD METALLIC SCREECHING NOISE As a UN JEEP, its tires shot out, sparks cascading from wheel rims, screams up to the guard house. Paul slams on the brakes. The jeep is followed by the two trucks, their canvas slashed fluttering in the wind. Paul throws the van into reverse and clears the way. The convoy pulls up in front of the hotel. Bloody and battered, the terrified refugees fall from the trucks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Paul and Odette run among the casualties. Then he sees them: Tatiana, clothes torn, scratches on her face. The kids screaming in terror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: runs to them, grabs, kisses, weeps louder. Battered refugees everywhere, other hotel residents looking on - equally terrified because: They know they are doomed. Paul sees Roger, trembling, tears soak his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He grabs Roger up. Tatiana struggles to Paul, embraces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tatiana breaks from the embrace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Paul shakes his head no.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Papa! Papa!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank God you are safe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did he bring the twins?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul sits alone on his secluded bench in the garden. cloud of despair shrouds him. As he watches several women dip cooking pots into the pool. e hurries toward them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is no water from the pipes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What are you doing?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: heads for the front doors. He's intercepted by the two Rwandan policemen stationed at the gate by Bizimungu.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: here is our beer? You promised us beer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Did you explain to the good General that I have temporarily run out of stock?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He said to ask Mitterand and the French to send you more.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You will get it in due time. Now, please, get back to the gate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY Paul enters, sees Zozo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: off.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What is this about no water?

result.heading: THE GENOCIDE ENDED IN LATE JUNE 1994, WHEN THE TUTSI REBELS DEFEATED THE HUTU ARMY AND MILITIA
TWO MILLION HUTUS FLED INTO THE NEIGHBORING CONGO IN THE LARGEST SINGLE EXODUS OF THE TWENTIETH CENTURY THEY LEFT BEHIND ALMOST ONE MILLION CORPSES

dialogue.raw_text: : GEORGE RUTAGUNDA George Rutagunda was convicted of crimes against humanity.   He is now serving a life sentence in a Tanzanian jail.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: : GENERAL BIZIMUNGU Augustin Bizimungu escaped with the Hutu Militia to the Congo. In August, 2002 he was captured in Angola. A UN war crimes tribunal has charged him with crimes against humanity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : THOMAS AND FEDENS                               Thomas' and Fedens' bodies where never found. Paul adopted their twin daughters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : PAUL (the lead actor)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : saved the lives of all one thousand two hundred Rwandan refugees who took shelter at the Mille Collines Hotel.
